results.headline: Searching China, Heart on Sleeve
results.summary_short: Zhang Yimou takes a pause between marital arts extravaganzas with this simple, affecting melodrama about a mournful Japanese patriarch on an odyssey through rural China.
results.display_title: Riding Alone for Thousands of Miles

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Riding Alone for Thousands of Miles

results.headline: Letting Go Is the Hard Part
results.summary_short: A disgruntled New York City private investigator forms an unlikely bond with a high school baseball coach from upstate in Edward Burns’s latest exercise in maleness.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Looking For Kitty

results.headline: On the Detroit Streets, Friends Strive for More Than Baskets
results.summary_short: Bling is bad and friends are good in this story of temptation, rivalry and buck-wild cheerleaders set in the world of Detroit street basketball.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Crossover

results.headline: The Organic Snack That Builds Character
results.summary_short: The film version of Thomas Rockwell's 1973 book proves refreshingly free of the customary blights that affect most modern children’s movies, notably adult condescension.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of How to Eat Fried Worms

results.headline: The Faces of Radical Islamic Martyrdom
results.summary_short: Pierre Rehov's haphazard inquiry into suicide bombing spends much of its brief running time replacing analysis with a litany of bummers.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Suicide Killers

results.headline: The Best of Friends, Until the Bloody End
results.summary_short: Neither ambitious enough to take seriously nor sleazy enough to enjoy, “The Quiet” flirts with the trappings of exploitation cinema without going all the way.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Quiet

results.headline: A Tale of Wedding Plans and Mothers Who Disrupt Them
results.summary_short: A dithering but generous Spanish farce, “Queens” follows the coming nuptials of three gay couples by focusing on their overbearing mothers.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Queens

results.headline: An Unlikely Rookie With a Gridiron Dream
results.summary_short: Disney's latest sports-underdog movie is the true story of a part-time bartender (Mark Wahlberg) who realizes his dream of playing for the Philadelphia Eagles.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Invincible

results.headline: Trust Me, Baby, the Joint Is Jumping and Singing
results.summary_short: The joint doesn’t jump in the OutKast musical “Idlewild”; it just twitches and stumbles.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Idlewild

results.headline: Adam and Eve in Search of a Million-Dollar Payday
results.summary_short: Although early scenes hold out some promise that this parody of “Survivor” could amount to something, the movie quickly runs out of ideas.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Surviving Eden

results.headline: Guzzling Brew to Protect the Family Name
results.summary_short: Best viewed while sloshed, "Beerfest" is idiotic, tasteless and irrepressibly good-natured — in other words, a frat-house classic.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Beerfest

results.headline: Logging On for Love, Tuning Out the Realities
results.summary_short: The inability to connect in a hyper-wired world is old news given fresh voice in this tragicomic indie about the way we live.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of LOL

results.headline: Working Girls With Dreams Beyond the Corner
results.summary_short: This maudlin melodrama about prostitutes in Madrid is not, alas, the new film by Pedro Almódovar, but a dilution of his manner by the writer-director Fernando León de Aranoa.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Princesas

results.headline: Escaping the Violence but Finding New Danger
results.summary_short: The familiar story of the innocent soul who travels from the country to the big, bad city receives a thorough workout in this crude attempt at a cinematic bildungsroman.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Fratricide

results.headline: ‘Snakes on a Plane’: That’s No Seat Belt Around Your Waist
results.summary_short: All anyone really needs to know about this amusingly crude, honestly satisfying artifact is snakes + plane + Samuel L. Jackson.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Snakes on a Plane

results.headline: In ‘Material Girls,’ Those Daffy Duff Sisters Play Rich, Daffy ... Sisters
results.summary_short: An incompetent spin on the poor-little-rich-girl story, the film involves a lot of wardrobe changes and product placements, and a smidgen of intrigue and some chaste romance.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Material Girls

results.headline: 'The Illusionist': How Does a Man of Mystery Survive? It’s Magic
results.summary_short: Neil Burger's screen adaptation of a short story by Steven Millhauser gives Edward Norton a role that perfectly fits his disturbing inscrutability.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Illusionist

results.headline: On the Barstool Again, With One for His Muse, in ‘Factotum’
results.summary_short: Matt Dillon inhabits the role of Henry Chinanski, the alter ego of the writer Charles Bukowski, in Bent Hamer's adaptation of Bukowski's 1975 novel of the same name.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Factotum

results.headline: ‘10th and Wolf’: Welcome Home From the War. Now Here’s an Offer You Can’t Refuse.
results.summary_short: A grisly gangster movie with moral pretensions, “10th and Wolf” never transcends mobster clichés recycled from “The Godfather,” “Donnie Brasco” and “GoodFellas.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of 10th and Wolf

results.headline: ‘Trust the Man’:  Two Couples Talk, Talk, Talk
results.summary_short: Opening a film with a small child straining on a toilet and talking about poop isn’t just a bad idea; it’s an invitation to unfortunate metaphor.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Trust the Man
